speaker: ARMADO
text: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit

speaker: ARMADO
text: grows melancholy?

speaker: BOY
text: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Why, sadness is one and the selfsame thing,

speaker: ARMADO
text: dear imp.

speaker: BOY
text: No, no. O Lord, sir, no!

speaker: ARMADO
text: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy,

speaker: ARMADO
text: my tender juvenal?

speaker: BOY
text: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my

speaker: BOY
text: tough signior.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Why “tough signior”? Why “tough signior”?

speaker: BOY
text: Why “tender juvenal”? Why “tender juvenal”?

speaker: ARMADO
text: I spoke it “tender juvenal” as a congruent

speaker: ARMADO
text: epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which

speaker: ARMADO
text: we may nominate “tender.”

speaker: BOY
text: And I “tough signior” as an appurtenant title to

speaker: BOY
text: your old time, which we may name “tough.”

speaker: ARMADO
text: Pretty and apt.

speaker: BOY
text: How mean you, sir? I pretty and my saying apt, or

speaker: BOY
text: I apt and my saying pretty?

speaker: ARMADO
text: Thou pretty because little.

speaker: BOY
text: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

speaker: ARMADO
text: And therefore apt, because quick.

speaker: BOY
text: Speak you this in my praise, master?

speaker: ARMADO
text: In thy condign praise.

speaker: BOY
text: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

speaker: ARMADO
text: What, that an eel is ingenious?

speaker: BOY
text: That an eel is quick.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I do say thou art quick in answers. Thou

speaker: ARMADO
text: heat’st my blood.

speaker: BOY
text: I am answered, sir.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I love not to be crossed.

speaker: BOY
text: He speaks the mere contrary; crosses love

speaker: BOY
text: not him.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I have promised to study three years with the

speaker: ARMADO
text: Duke.

speaker: BOY
text: You may do it in an hour, sir.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Impossible.

speaker: BOY
text: How many is one thrice told?

speaker: ARMADO
text: I am ill at reckoning. It fitteth the spirit of a

speaker: ARMADO
text: tapster.

speaker: BOY
text: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I confess both. They are both the varnish of a

speaker: ARMADO
text: complete man.

speaker: BOY
text: Then I am sure you know how much the gross

speaker: BOY
text: sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

speaker: ARMADO
text: It doth amount to one more than two.

speaker: BOY
text: Which the base vulgar do call “three.”

speaker: ARMADO
text: True.

speaker: BOY
text: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here is

speaker: BOY
text: “three” studied ere you’ll thrice wink. And how

speaker: BOY
text: easy it is to put “years” to the word “three” and

speaker: BOY
text: study “three years” in two words, the dancing horse

speaker: BOY
text: will tell you.

speaker: ARMADO
text: A most fine figure.

speaker: BOY
text: To prove you a cipher.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I will hereupon confess I am in love; and as it

speaker: ARMADO
text: is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a

speaker: ARMADO
text: base wench. If drawing my sword against the

speaker: ARMADO
text: humor of affection would deliver me from the

speaker: ARMADO
text: reprobate thought of it, I would take desire prisoner

speaker: ARMADO
text: and ransom him to any French courtier for a

speaker: ARMADO
text: new-devised curtsy. I think scorn to sigh; methinks

speaker: ARMADO
text: I should outswear Cupid. Comfort me, boy. What

speaker: ARMADO
text: great men have been in love?

speaker: BOY
text: Hercules, master.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear

speaker: ARMADO
text: boy, name more; and, sweet my child, let them be

speaker: ARMADO
text: men of good repute and carriage.

speaker: BOY
text: Samson, master; he was a man of good carriage,

speaker: BOY
text: great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his

speaker: BOY
text: back like a porter, and he was in love.

speaker: ARMADO
text: O, well-knit Samson, strong-jointed Samson;

speaker: ARMADO
text: I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst

speaker: ARMADO
text: me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was

speaker: ARMADO
text: Samson’s love, my dear Mote?

speaker: BOY
text: A woman, master.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Of what complexion?

speaker: BOY
text: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of

speaker: BOY
text: the four.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

speaker: BOY
text: Of the sea-water green, sir.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Is that one of the four complexions?

speaker: BOY
text: As I have read, sir, and the best of them too.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Green indeed is the color of lovers. But to

speaker: ARMADO
text: have a love of that color, methinks Samson had

speaker: ARMADO
text: small reason for it. He surely affected her for her

speaker: ARMADO
text: wit.

speaker: BOY
text: It was so, sir, for she had a green wit.

speaker: ARMADO
text: My love is most immaculate white and red.

speaker: BOY
text: Most maculate thoughts, master, are masked

speaker: BOY
text: under such colors.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Define, define, well-educated infant.

speaker: BOY
text: My father’s wit and my mother’s tongue, assist

speaker: BOY
text: me.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Sweet invocation of a child, most pretty and

speaker: ARMADO
text: pathetical.

speaker: BOY
text: A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of

speaker: BOY
text: white and red.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Is there not a ballad, boy, of The King and

speaker: ARMADO
text: the Beggar?

speaker: BOY
text: The world was very guilty of such a ballad some

speaker: BOY
text: three ages since, but I think now ’tis not to be found;

speaker: BOY
text: or if it were, it would neither serve for the writing

speaker: BOY
text: nor the tune.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I will have that subject newly writ o’er, that I

speaker: ARMADO
text: may example my digression by some mighty precedent.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in

speaker: ARMADO
text: the park with the rational hind Costard. She deserves

speaker: ARMADO
text: well.

speaker: BOY
text: To be whipped—and yet a better love than

speaker: BOY
text: my master.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Sing, boy. My spirit grows heavy in love.

speaker: BOY
text: And that’s great marvel, loving a light

speaker: BOY
text: wench.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I say sing.

speaker: BOY
text: Forbear till this company be past.

speaker: DULL
text: Sir, the Duke’s pleasure is that you

speaker: DULL
text: keep Costard safe, and you must suffer him to take

speaker: DULL
text: no delight, nor no penance, but he must fast three

speaker: DULL
text: days a week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the

speaker: DULL
text: park. She is allowed for the dey-woman. Fare you

speaker: DULL
text: well.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I do betray myself with blushing.—

speaker: ARMADO
text: Maid.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text: Man.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I will visit thee at the lodge.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text: That’s hereby.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I know where it is situate.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text: Lord, how wise you are.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I will tell thee wonders.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text: With that face?

speaker: ARMADO
text: I love thee.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text: So I heard you say.

speaker: ARMADO
text: And so, farewell.

speaker: JAQUENETTA
text: Fair weather after you.

speaker: DULL
text: Come, Jaquenetta, away.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy

speaker: ARMADO
text: offenses ere thou be pardoned.

speaker: COSTARD
text: Well, sir, I hope when I do it I shall do it on

speaker: COSTARD
text: a full stomach.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

speaker: COSTARD
text: I am more bound to you than your fellows,

speaker: COSTARD
text: for they are but lightly rewarded.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Take away this villain. Shut him up.

speaker: BOY
text: Come, you transgressing slave, away.

speaker: COSTARD
text: Let me not be pent up, sir. I will

speaker: COSTARD
text: fast being loose.

speaker: BOY
text: No, sir, that were fast and loose. Thou shalt to

speaker: BOY
text: prison.

speaker: COSTARD
text: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of

speaker: COSTARD
text: desolation that I have seen, some shall see.

speaker: BOY
text: What shall some see?

speaker: COSTARD
text: Nay, nothing, Master Mote, but what they

speaker: COSTARD
text: look upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent in

speaker: COSTARD
text: their words, and therefore I will say nothing. I thank

speaker: COSTARD
text: God I have as little patience as another man, and

speaker: COSTARD
text: therefore I can be quiet.

speaker: ARMADO
text: I do affect the very ground (which is base)

speaker: ARMADO
text: where her shoe (which is baser) guided by her foot

speaker: ARMADO
text: (which is basest) doth tread. I shall be forsworn

speaker: ARMADO
text: (which is a great argument of falsehood) if I love.

speaker: ARMADO
text: And how can that be true love which is falsely

speaker: ARMADO
text: attempted? Love is a familiar; love is a devil. There is

speaker: ARMADO
text: no evil angel but love, yet was Samson so tempted,

speaker: ARMADO
text: and he had an excellent strength; yet was Solomon

speaker: ARMADO
text: so seduced, and he had a very good wit. Cupid’s

speaker: ARMADO
text: butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules’ club, and therefore

speaker: ARMADO
text: too much odds for a Spaniard’s rapier. The first

speaker: ARMADO
text: and second cause will not serve my turn; the

speaker: ARMADO
text: passado he respects not, the duello he regards not.

speaker: ARMADO
text: His disgrace is to be called “boy,” but his glory is to

speaker: ARMADO
text: subdue men. Adieu, valor; rust, rapier; be still,

speaker: ARMADO
text: drum, for your manager is in love. Yea, he loveth.

speaker: ARMADO
text: Assist me, some extemporal god of rhyme, for I am

speaker: ARMADO
text: sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise wit, write pen, for I

speaker: ARMADO
text: am for whole volumes in folio.
